utterances: John Hendren, NPR News, Washington
Looking at a picture here of a crew-cut Donald Rumsfeld in 1963.
It's part of a timeline in pictures of Donald Rumsfeld's career, and it's at npr.org.
From NPR News, this is All Things Considered.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
The city of Boston feels a little better about itself today.
Shortly after the clock struck midnight, the Red Sox concluded a remarkable comeback in Fenway Park, to live another day in the American League Championship Series.
Stefan Fatsis join us Fridays to talk about sports, and since he stayed up really late to watch that game, we're going to talk baseball stuff, and are you sleepy?
No. I'm awake now.
We wouldn't stand by it if an employer demanded that they could rifle through your U.S.
Postal Service deliveries or get your email password.
28-year-old single mom Cherise Scott is preparing for a double blow.
She handles medical records at the Miners Family Health Center in the small town of Grass Valley in the Sierra Nevada foothills.
The budget impasse may force the clinic to shut down, and she'd be out of a job.
She'd also be without a health clinic for herself and her three kids, eight-month-old twins and an eight-year-old.
Shots, immunizations, colds, I come here for all of that.
Scott says Miners is one of the only clinics near her rural town of Smartville that takes Californians on the public health program Medicaid or Medi-Cal, as it's called here.
It's a concern because, without Medi-Cal, I don't have health coverage at all, which means I would have to pay out of my pocket, and I can't afford to do that either, with gas prices.
And with these obstacles, Scott says she may have to face some tough decisions.
I probably - yeah, probably wouldn't just go with the doctor, use the ER with major things that I needed.
Like most community health clinics across the state, the Miners Family Health Center gets about half of its funding from state Medi-Cal dollars.
That money ran out in mid-July.
The clinic treats about a third of Grass Valley and neighboring Nevada City residents, mainly low income and elderly patients.
Clinic CEO Scott McFarland says it will only get worse.
He says the clinic's $300,000 short-term emergency credit line is about to run out.
He didn't plan for the budget gridlock to go on for more than six weeks.
And it's a serious reality that, if this budget goes into November, there are going to have to be some real serious consequences.
We may have to close at that point.
That would mean about 30 people would lose their jobs.
And McFarland says it would be hard to reopen after the budget passes and clinics are paid back.
Miners still owes about $250,000 in interest payments on loans they took out in previous years to cover late budgets.
It's disappointing, and it's frustrating and it's scary.
You know, even for myself, you know, how am I going to pay my bills if Miners isn't open?
And what am I going to do with my staff?
How do you explain this to your staff?
How do you explain this to 30,000 patients that, we're sorry.
We can't provide the service any longer?
Carmella Castellano-Garcia says a lot of clinics are in the same situation as Miners.
She's with the California Primary Care Association, which advocates for community health clinics across the state.
The longer this unprecedented stalled budget drags out, she says, the more it will cripple providers.
I think we are really on the brink of a turning point for the health centers and their ability to hold out.
The fact that there's no end in sight is what really makes this particularly precarious.
What is certain is, if the budget impasse continues for much longer, some California residents will see community clinics in their area close.
For NPR News, I'm Kelley Weiss in Sacramento.
(Soundbite of music)
This week, General Ray Odierno took over as the top American commander in Iraq.
Upon his arrival, Odierno said it's up to the Iraqi people to take charge now, though there is still plenty of work for the U.S.
military to do.
One of those troops is someone that we've been hearing from on our show.
His name is Captain Nate Rawlings, and he is a young Princeton alum who is currently stop-lossed in Iraq.
And over the past few months, he has been sending us updates and taking your questions at our website, npr.org.

And you can go to npr.org/nate where you'll find the latest, an essay about having to blow his nose while on a mission, and his response to a listener who calls him a, quote, ""gutless murderer."" That's at npr.org/nate.
The men's NCAA college basketball tournament starts next week.
This year, there's a new a twist on the familiar March Madness bracket contest.
World-famous investor Warren Buffett has teamed up with a mortgage company to offer a billion dollars to anyone who picks the winner of all 63 games in the tournament.
In other words, a perfect bracket.
As NPR's Uri Berliner reports, the contest for the perfect bracket may also be the perfect publicity stunt.
All right.
Let's introduce the players.
There's Quicken Loans, the mortgage company that's sponsoring the contest.
Investor Warren Buffett - he's the insurance man here - willing to pay out the $1 billion if someone wins.
Then there's Yahoo - you need one of their accounts to enter.
And finally, as many as 15 million people who will sign up to play.
Maybe you've heard on sports shows like ""Crowd Goes Wild"" the odds of picking a perfect bracket are not good.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: If you do win it - and you've got a one-in 9.2 quintillion chance...
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: Quintillion.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: But if you do win it, there's a choice to be made, Regis.
Nine quintillion.
That's a nine followed by 18 zeroes.
That's not the kind of number we actually use on this planet.
It's like something a couple of 10-year-olds might invent during a sleepover.
Jeffrey Bergen says don't worry about quintillions.
He's a math professor at DePaul University.
Those odds assume every game in the tournament is a toss-up, but in the early rounds, highly ranked teams usually win.
So, he's got his own number.
One in 128 billion, if you know something about college basketball.
But let's put those odds in perspective.
If you have a favorite baseball team, they are more likely to win the next seven consecutive World Series than you are - with knowledge of basketball - to get a perfect bracket.
If you sat down today and tried to predict the winning party in every presidential election through 2160, getting that correct is more likely than getting a perfect bracket.
And if you sat down now with fair coin and flipped it, you're more likely to get 37 heads in a row than you are to get a perfect bracket.
He could go on - believe me.
One in 128 billion won't keep Warren Buffett up at night, and that's what makes this such an inspired contest.
And let's go next to Melissa(ph), Melissa with us from Owatonna in Minnesota.
We don't have control over our border.
We're not prepared for known biological attacks.
And Heyman says no one really knows the most effective way to secure cargo.
The candidates' overall philosophies are also unclear.
Are we more secure by putting more security in place?
Or are we more secure by integrating across the globe in a better way?
Heyman says these things matter.
Americans might be worrying less and less about an attack, but most security experts think the threat is as great as ever.
His homeland security policy right now is thoroughly intertwined with his understanding that we have to be successful in Iraq.
That's McCain's senior policy adviser, Douglas Holtz-Eakin.
He says McCain thinks the best way to prevent another attack is to stop al-Qaida from getting a foothold in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Holtz-Eakin acknowledges that the campaign Web site doesn't mention homeland security as a major issue, but he says the Republican senator has a strong record to run on.
He was one of the leaders in the effort to clear the digital spectrum so that we could have first responders that could communicate with one another.
Something they couldn't do at the World Trade Center and again during Hurricane Katrina.
McCain has also pushed for stronger border security, especially after it became clear that would be a prerequisite for his plan to reform immigration.
Maybe we don't call that a homeland security initiative, but it's obviously an important accomplishment in that regard.
McCain has also said if there's another Katrina-like disaster, he'll use the private sector as a model to make sure emergency supplies get where they're needed.
Obama agrees with McCain that Katrina was one of the Bush administration's greatest failures, and says in his administration the FEMA director would report directly to him.
Unlike McCain, Obama has a whole section on his campaign Web site devoted to homeland security.
Stephen Flynn, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, is an unpaid adviser to the campaign.

He says the biggest difference between the candidates is that the Democrat thinks money spent on Iraq would be better spent domestically - on critical infrastructure - so the country is better able to withstand another attack.
The more brittle we are as a society - as unfortunately the poor citizens of New Orleans learned - the more consequential disasters, whether they be manmade or natural, are going to be.
Obama has also pushed to target homeland security funds at cities that face the greatest threat, and to impose tougher restrictions on chemical plants.
He also thinks all Americans should share in the burden of protecting the nation, a topic he raised in a speech last year in Washington.
Too often, this administration's approach to homeland security has been to scatter money around and avoid hard choices, or to scare Americans without telling them what to be scared of or what to do.
He said if elected, he'll share threat information with the public and with local officials.
